comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
Since 1860, (following similar work on Essex Bridge - now Grattan Bridge), to improve the streetscape and relieve traffic congestion on the bridge, it was intended to widen Carlisle Bridge to bring it to the same width as 70 metres (230 ft) wide Sackville Street (now O'Connell Street) which formed the north side carriageway connection to the Bridge.[2] In 1877-1880 the bridge was reconstructed. As can be seen on orthophotography [3] it spans now 45 m of the Liffey and is about 50 m wide. O'Connell Bridge is said to be unique in Europe as the only traffic bridge as wide as it is long.

So pre 1877 at least!

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: When the bridge was reopened c.1882 it was renamed for Daniel O'Connell when the statue in his honour was unveiled.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] Thanks, I thought as much but surprised by the number.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] This note states that there were 23,000 lime kilns in the 18th Century!!!! I am amazed at this number.

There were also kilns used for grain drying.

The use of lime for agriculture purposes began in Ireland in the 12th century, possibly a Norman introduction, dressing soil with lime was in widespread use by the mid 1600's. County Cork seems to have had a prodigious number of kilns at the end of the 18th century it is thought the county had somewhere around 23,000 in operation which amounts to one for every 80 acres, if these figures are correct the industry must have employed a considerable number of people

comment.author: 97278156@N08
comment._content: the life grate

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
Building on the right...

1859 - Dissolution of Partnership from 20th September 1859
- between Charles Toole and James William Mackey, "Toole and Mackey" . 
"Charles Toole the Senior partner will carry on with his son "Toole & Co"
at 41 Westmoreland Street, Dublin". 
Published in the Irish Times on 22nd September 1859

I presume Mackey is associated with the Mackey seed business of Mary street?

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
40 Westmoreland St Mackey, James Wm. alderman, J.P.
wholes, seed merchant  - 1862

So even though Mackey and Toole dissolved their partnership in 1859  - in 1962 they are in opposition in adjoining premises on this street.

I bet it was not a happy dissolution of the partnership!!
